title: How to Bake a Vegetable Tart

steps.headline: Collect ingredients, and make sure there is a lot of tomato for juiciness.
steps.description: Small round courgettes are best for presentational purposes, but a normal one is fine too.

steps.headline: Thinly slice your selected vegetables, cutting the tomato either in slices or quarters, and everything else as thinly as possible.
Spread pastry into a suitably sized baking tin.
steps.description: Score a 1 centimeter (0.4 in) border around the outside, and prick inside the line with a fork, ensuring you don't leave any spaces as the pastry won't rise properly.

steps.headline: Bake for 10 minutes at 200 °C (392 °F) degrees (adjust cooking times appropriately for fan-assisted ovens) or until the pastry becomes golden and has risen significantly in the middle, as shown.
Squash down hard inside the border with a fork.
Liberally spread pesto inside the border (it can be substituted for other sauces, but it's the best for flavour without sogginess) and add chopped garlic and mixed herbs.
Spread courgette, peppers and any other large vegetables you want to add, making sure they are evenly distributed (as on a pizza.)
Make sure tomatoes are on top.
steps.description: That's important, as otherwise they lose flavour against the pesto.

steps.headline: Add any olives and other herbs you want to use.
steps.description: This is the best place to pop your smaller vegetables and really add a bit of colour to the tart.

steps.headline: Bake for 15 minutes, or until the tart is cooked and the border is golden.
steps.description: Slice up into quarters for lunch and half for dinner, and serve with a bit of salad on the side and a nice white wine.

text: Collect ingredients, and make sure there is a lot of tomato for juiciness. Small round courgettes are best for presentational purposes, but a normal one is fine too. Thinly slice your selected vegetables, cutting the tomato either in slices or quarters, and everything else as thinly as possible.  Spread pastry into a suitably sized baking tin. Score a 1 centimeter (0.4 in) border around the outside, and prick inside the line with a fork, ensuring you don't leave any spaces as the pastry won't rise properly. Bake for 10 minutes at 200 °C (392 °F) degrees (adjust cooking times appropriately for fan-assisted ovens) or until the pastry becomes golden and has risen significantly in the middle, as shown.  Squash down hard inside the border with a fork.  Liberally spread pesto inside the border (it can be substituted for other sauces, but it's the best for flavour without sogginess) and add chopped garlic and mixed herbs.  Spread courgette, peppers and any other large vegetables you want to add, making sure they are evenly distributed (as on a pizza.)  Make sure tomatoes are on top. That's important, as otherwise they lose flavour against the pesto. Add any olives and other herbs you want to use. This is the best place to pop your smaller vegetables and really add a bit of colour to the tart. Bake for 15 minutes, or until the tart is cooked and the border is golden. Slice up into quarters for lunch and half for dinner, and serve with a bit of salad on the side and a nice white wine. Finished.
